resource.chars:
14. 
mile. No competent surveyor would imagine that 
vertical heights could be obtained under the circumstances 
'within three feet' and I am forced to add that no person 
practically conversant with surveying methods could have 
made the statement to which Dr Shaw is alleged to have 
committed himself. 
In reviewing the concluding remarks of Dr Shaw's 
preface I am obliged to enter the region of controversy, 
but this is connected with matters already discussed, 
in as much as I find it difficult to avoid the conclusion 
that the doubts thrown on Lieutenant Royds' observations 
have been prompted by a desire to prove that the Easterly 
wind experienced at Winter Quarters was a 'true' wind. 
As Dr Shaw mentions (page X11) I and other 
members of the Expedition "brought back the general 
impression that the winds at Winter Quarters were a local 
phenomenon and that in open situations the prevailing 
wind was really from the South West." 
To show that the prevalent wind in our region 
is Westerly is to prove a fact which is in direct 
opposition to the Anticyclonic theory. 
Dr Shaw has touched lightly on our impression 
and failed to mention any of the observations that 
<u>created<\u>
